articles.author: EMMA BURROWS, DASHA LITVINOVA and JIM HEINTZ
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin basked in a victory early Monday that was never in doubt, as partial election results showed him easily securing a fifth term after facing only token challengers and harshly suppressing opposition voices.
articles.title: Putin basks in electoral victory that was never in doubt even as Russians quietly protest

articles.author: DASHA LITVINOVA
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin said early Monday that he supported an idea to release opposition leader Alexei Navalny in a prisoner exchange just days before the man who was his biggest foe died.
articles.title: Commenting on Navalny's death for first time, Putin says he supported prisoner swap for his foe

articles.author: TIA GOLDENBERG and RAVI NESSMAN
articles.description: TEL AVIV, Israel (AP) — Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu railed Sunday against growing criticism from top ally the United States against his leadership amid the devastating war with Hamas, describing calls for a new election as “wholly inappropriate.”
articles.title: Netanyahu snaps back against growing US criticism after being accused of losing his way on Gaza

articles.author: KIRSTEN GRIESHABER
articles.description: BERLIN (AP) — When Sabine Thonke joined a recent demonstration in Berlin against Germany's far-right party, it was the first time in years she felt hopeful that the growing power of the extremists in her country could be stopped.
articles.title: In Germany, the far right is on the rise again. How did it happen?

articles.description: MIAMI (AP) — A charter flight carrying dozens of U.S. citizens fleeing spiraling gang violence in Haiti landed Sunday in Miami, U.S.
articles.title: First charter flight with US citizens fleeing Haiti lands in Miami

articles.author: MARK SHERMAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — In a busy term that could set standards for free speech in the digital age, the Supreme Court is taking up a dispute Monday between Republican-led states and the Biden administration over how far the federal government can go to combat controversial social media posts on topics like COVID-19 and election security.
articles.title: Supreme Court weighs how far federal officials can go to combat controversial posts on hot topics

articles.author: REBECCA BOONE
articles.description: BOISE, Idaho (AP) — Idaho lawmakers are expected to vote this week on a bill that would ban the use of any public funds for gender-affirming care, including for state employees using work health insurance and for adults covered by Medicaid.
articles.title: Idaho considers a ban on using public funds or facilities for gender-affirming care

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: BOSTON (AP) — While some American cities celebrated St.
articles.title: AP PHOTOS: Boston celebrates St. Patrick's Day; Biden holds White House brunch with Irish leader

articles.author: NICK PERRY and LISA RATHKE
articles.description: ELMORE, Vt. (AP) — Julie wants more donations to the food pantry. Kipp is busy knitting a sweater. Shorty is ready to ask: Why is so much being spent on a truck? The coffee, fresh-baked bread and donuts have been laid out.
articles.title: In Vermont, 'Town Meeting' is democracy embodied. What can the rest of the country learn from it?

articles.description: BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) — Colombian President Gustavo Petro on Sunday suspended a ceasefire with one of a handful of armed groups with which he hoped to negotiate peace accords, saying its fighters violated the truce by attacking an Indigenous community.
articles.title: Colombia suspends ceasefire with faction of ex-FARC rebels following attack on Indigenous community
